paragraphs.text: Christian ex-fire chief fires back at Atlanta mayor, files discrimination complaint.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Former Atlanta Fire Chief Kelvin Cochran says he was fired because he wrote a book expressing his Christian faith, according to a discrimination complaint filed Jan  19 with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "I believe that I have been discriminated against because of my religion," Cochran wrote in the complaint
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: His attorney, Jeremy Tedesco of the Alliance Defending Freedom, a Christian legal organization that advocates for the right of people to freely live out their faith, said the ADA wants to vindicate the former fire chief following his "unjust termination."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Americans are guaranteed the freedom to live without fear of losing their jobs because of their beliefs and thoughts," Tedesco said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Atlanta Mayor Kasim Reed threatened that the former fire chief's reputation would be destroyed should he file a lawsuit
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "He's gon na lose," Reed told television station WAGA
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "And in the process his reputation is going to be destroyed because people are going to see he's dishonest."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The EEOC complaint is the latest move in a battle between Cochran and Reed that has generated a national debate over religious liberty in the public marketplace
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: since
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it began in November
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cochran was suspended without pay on Nov  24 for writing a book about biblical morality,"Who Told You That You Were Naked?"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He said homosexuality is "vile" and listed it among other forms of "sexual perversions."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He was also accused of giving the book to colleagues at work with whom he had personal friendships
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: An investigation by the city of Atlanta found that "firefighters throughout the organization are appalled by the sentiments expressed in the book."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The report went on to say that "there is also general agreement the contents of the book have eroded trust and have compromised the ability of the chief to provide leadership in the future."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: CLICK HERE TO JOIN TODD ON FACEBOOK FOR CONSERVATIVE CONVERSATION!
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: But the investigation found no evidence of discrimination against LGBT firefighters
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "There is currently no indication that Chief Cochran allowed his religious beliefs to compromise his disciplinary decisions," the report states
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "No interviewed witness could point to a specific instance in which any member of the organization has been treated unfairly by Chief Cochran on the basis of his religious beliefs."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cochran was cleared of any wrongdoing
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But on Jan  6 - the day he was supposed to return to work- he was fired
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The mayor denied that Cochran's faith had anything to do with his dismissal
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Instead
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: he said it was lack of judgment and management skills
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He also said Cochran violated the city's code of conduct
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Folks, this was nothing short of an old-fashioned witch hunt led by the mayor, LGBT activists and the city's left-wing firefighter's union
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to the city's investigation, they interviewed a retired lesbian battalion chief who harbored "suspicions" about Cochran's Christian faith
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "She stated that she took a voluntary demotion because of these suspicions," the report states
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: What a load of fertilizer
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The Atlanta Professional Firefighters Local 134 piled on, commending the mayor for firing the Christian fire chief
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "Local 134 supports LGBT rights and equality among all employees," the union said in a statement, urging the city to "improve LGBT rights by adding an LGBT liaison for the fire department."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Now
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the leadership of Local 134 is either ignorant or illiterate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because the official investigation clearly shows the fire chief NEVER DISCRIMINATED AGAINST LGBT FIREFIGHTERS
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The New York Times editorial board said it doesn't matter if Chief Cochran was innocent
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: That's not the point, it wrote Tuesday in a scathing editorial titled"God, Gays and the Atlanta Fire Department."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "It should not matter that the investigation found no evidence that Mr  Cochran had mistreated gays or lesbians," the Times wrote
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "His position as a high-level public servant makes his remarks especially problematic, and requires that he be held to a different standard."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The mayor may have the LGBT activists, the union and The New York Times on his side
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Chief Cochran has some much bigger firepower - the nation's evangelical community
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Leading the charge is Franklin Graham, president of the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Graham told me he's known Cochran for years- and found him to be a decent and honorable man
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He said Cochran has become the latest victim of a national cleansing of Christians in the public marketplace
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "We need to stand up with Chief Cochran and others when they are persecuted," Graham told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "This man is being persecuted because he believes the Bible."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Robert White, executive director of the Georgia Baptist Convention, called The New York Times editorial "quite remarkable."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "It declares his innocence and then declares him guilty," he said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Guilty of what? He didn't discriminate against any homosexuals
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He vowed that he wanted to have a healthy workplace for all of his employees."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The Times went on to argue that while Cochran is free to believe whatever he wants, there are limits to where he can believe and still maintain gainful employment in the public arena
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I didn't know better
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I'd say The New York Times is suggesting a"Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy for public workers who happen to be Christian
paragraphs.label: assumption
